These are the three pieces that will fit the Acrylic version of the i3 currently being sold on ebay

I had to rework the size for the X axis as the ones that were out here were too thick

The Y axis is a simple rework of the one that came with the machine

Has greatly improved the performance of this machine

Rev1: I changed the Y axis tensioner because i noticed that it still moved up and down a little simply because it was suspended by only the two screws, so i added feet to go through the brace that holds it steady. If you don't have those holes you can use the original. i must tell you that with this improvement i was able to print the new piece and it fit perfectly without any cleanup at all.

I should also note that you will loose about 16 mm on the X axis because of this.

comments.text:
This answer will be a bit longer... ;-) I've thought about that long before I started modelling. There are many reasons, why I didn't do that:
First of all: This model is for 3D printers. They have a lot of different settings. Say, I'd add a little hole under the surface to move the center of mass, it could work for someone who prints with 100% infill. If someone else prints with 10% infill and three shells, there would be added more plastic around the hole which would have the opposite effect to the center of mass.
The second reason is, that most infill prints are not balanced. Even if it seems so in X and Y axis, at least the Z axis is out of balance.
I've also found a third issue: Even if you print with 100% infill, most printers don't print homogeneous enough. They produce round "snakes" of plastic and print them as close next to the other as possible. There are some areas with less plastic and some others where the plastic was squeezed in. Even a perfect printed sphere would not be in perfect balance.
There would be a chance, if someone would like to mill the D20 out of a solid block of say aluminium, but than he could not mill a hole inside the dice. ;-)
So: I would think of that issue again, if we can print perfectly solid, homogeneous material.
Hope that answered your question. ;-)
comments.author: daegs

comments.text: I can print perfectly solid, homogeneous material.  If you make a balanced one I'll print it and send it to you.

description.text:
This handy device allows you to hang a pair of headphones from any flat vertical surface with a 1/4in bolt, screw, etc. It was originally designed for me to mount my headphones onto my home built computer cart made of 80/20 15-series aluminum tubing as seen in the pics. I discovered that if you print two sets of these hooks, it also works to hold a PS4 controller.
It is three easy to print parts, the base and the left and right hooks. They simply slide in place and are held there by the pressure of the plate onto the vertical surface. I would recommend a bit of super glue on the plate slot for extra strength.
The plate is 1.5in x 1.5in and the hooks stick out 2in.

this is one of my entries in the #MakerEdChallenge It is a wind powered Ferris wheel. I got the idea from the old sawmills that have belt drive from a steam traction engine, and I thought, why not substitute a wind turbine for the traction engine? So off I went. The first thing I designed was the turbine (the first one!). It was going pretty smoothly until I tried to fit all of the parts together. I had designed the tolerances to be too tight! and plus my printer is not, well, top of the line, as you say. Even worse the driven shaft had too much friction because of the long tube that it fits through. So I drilled it out and all was OK. Second I made the jack shaft that runs between the turbine and the Ferris wheel. It had little friction because the brackets are thinner. Finally i went on to the Ferris wheel its self! Designing was a breeze. But halfway through printing (I had printed all but the little seats for it) the ramps board shorted. So, here i am, waiting for the board so I can finish printing. But after I stared at the first turbine i designed. I figured i could make it look less archaic. That was the start of V2 turbine. But as i said before, I cant print right now. So for now i am dead in the water.

As of now what i have featured is the prototype and its really messy. My printer is on the fritz but as soon as I get another ramps board in the mail ill print the newest turbine(v2 stuff)

UPDATE 7-23-15 10:39 A.M. I have uploaded the rest of the files for the power part of it. I am going to bring the carnival part of it later...

https://youtu.be/THDdqx1kwdk

https://youtu.be/-eMmR1Vd-40

https://youtu.be/FxWn3jz3c68

To break it in I ran it for an hour with a liberal amount of vegetable oil. Graphite would have been better but i didn't have any. try to make it as friction less as possible.

Printing instructions:

(bracket_driveshaft) Print at 0.3 mm with minimal support material

+++++++++++++++++Drive assembly (blade_hub) Needs support material but not much. Print at 0.2 mm
(blade) Also needs support material. Print at 0.3 mm
(shaft) Needs to be very straight and true. Print at 0.1 mm with low heat
(bevel_gear_driver) Print at 0.2 mm
(bushing_drive) Print at 0.1 mm
+++++++++++++++++++++++
+++++++Driven Assembly (bevel_gear_driven) Print at 0.2 mm
(shaft_driven) Print at 0.1 mm with low heat
(bushing_driven) Print at 0.2 mm
(drive_pulley) Print at 0.1 mm with minimal support
++++++++++++++++++++

print v2 things for a better looking wind turbine.

The top and bottom halves of these boxes are identical. Boxes are formed by locking two halves together. The boxes are all derivatives of a polyhedron with 14 faces; 2 hexagons and 12 pentagons. The three versions are differently scaled. OpenSCAD code is included.

The boxes were printed with PLA on a Replicator using 0.3 mm layers and 2 shells.
To form a box press two halves together. The basic polyhedron's fit is tight and it is difficult to open. Use an electronic case opening pry tool for the basic polyhedron. The elongated version can be twisted and then pulled apart. A thumb nail can be inserted in the join of the flattened version and the other thumb used to grasp a point and pull the box apart. A more easily opened basic form, basic_sphere_1_6.stl, has been added.

description.text:
These were created as a D&D campaign's BBEG's elite troops.

Fantastic Nazism in our setting is pro-human to the point where they seek to drive out the "non-human beasts" from the Reichlands (Human kingdom modeled on Barbarossa's German Kingdoms.)

It's a good way to start the conversation, especially when we have an analogue of the Treaty of Versailles that the goblin-financed Dwarven and Elven armies forced the human king to sign to end the Human Expansion attempts.

The Human King bypassed the rule of no Royal Army by merging church and state, then training a Royal militia, and having the church provide Wizards, and mounted Clerics and Paladins for a Heilger Blitzkreig.

description.text:
IF YOU PRINT ONE, POST IT!

One of my good friends just had a baby! He is an amazing fashion photographer and designer so i don't dare try to pick out a shower gift for him and his wife that includes any sort of outfit or blanket... (No need to embarrass myself.)

Instead, I wanted to help him start early instilling a deep love of photography in his daughter in hopes that one day she and her daddy can enjoy it together.

So I created a 3D Printable toy camera for her. Almost all edges are rounded to make for a safe toy for really little flail-ers and so bigger kids won't hurt themselves if they fall on it. The small handle on the side is great for tiny hands or a big loop for a camera strap later on. The viewfinder is tapered out and gives a great perspective for the budding photog! Print one today for your little artist.

NOTE:
Be sure to print with support due to the handle not being flat on the build platform.

I added my friends daughters name to this but you can use any CAD program to do this as well. If you don't know how, ask google, she knows everything!

PRO TIP:
If you wait until it is about 40% printed and add some dry rice into the infill you can make this into a nice little rattle! i printed this with 15% infill to allow lots and lots of room for the dry rice note that some rice may get blown out if printing in PLA due to the directed fan... just keep adding more until you are satisfied. Rage! Rage against the blowing of the rice!

Also to keep the sound well muffled and not too sharp i printed this with 3 shells.

A 30mm & 40mm fan mount/cover with built in spacers.

Twice the fans = Twice the cooling right?

I made this because my e3D v6 hotend on my prusa i3 would clog whenever I used Cura because the hot end would pre-heat, home, then start the print and my fan wouldn't kick on until the print started... Even using the M106 G.code command (fan always on), it still waited until after the print started to turn the fan on (which was long enough for the nozzle to clog).

With this setup, you can attach another 40mm fan right on top of the 30mm fan that comes standard with the e3D v6 hotend, and wire the 40mm fan directly to your power supply. That way, the fan is always on if the printers on.

This thing could also be used to stack 2+ fans in any other configuration you can think of.

~20 min print @ .4
~5 min print @ .8

Hope you enjoy!

http://www.wize3d.com

comments.text: You could have connected the 30mm Fan direct to your powersupply? Why not?
comments.author: Golo87

comments.text: Because Marlin doesn't control the fan speed when the fans not connected to the RAMPS board.
comments.author: Golo87

description.text: I decided to just come up with a calibration method without even reading up on what others have done.  I'm sure this is idiotic, but there you go.

Enter some starting values for cubes 1 through 4 and also the extrusion width you plan to use from your slicer. Then enter your measured values into the Google Sheets doc: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0AlgQOeq77lH0dHc5cTl3alUxTm14ODQ5M0RYblhUd2c&usp=sharing And tweak the x, y, z and e calibration factors to try to come to the lowest overall difference values. And please let me know how idiotic this method is.

author: cryon

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7AruobipFGd

The Printrbot Play is great, but that pesky cable bundle always looks like it will get hooked on the print bed. After a print of mine suspiciously appeared to shift about a centimeter in the Y direction I knew something had to be done. Seriously, life is too short to worry about something this dumb. Fix the problem forever with this!

First off, a shout out to Andy Leer who's groundbreaking work on the legendary "Printrbot Play Cable Shelf" paved the way for the next generation of Printerbot Play cable management devices.

The "Tamer" is wide enough that the cable bundle won't slip and fall between the bed and the base while being tall enough that it won't rub on the bed either. Just clip it on the rear left wall of the housing and forget about it. If You're a bit concerned that it may slide off and cause a fire or something, shim it with some paper or tape - or hot glue it in place!

Hope you like it!

title: Bracket for Attachment of Caliper to Mini Lathe Tailstock

description.text:
8/18/15 Update
I've added a new STL version with 'quick release.' This works great if you only need the caliper attachment occasionally.

(Note... The rendering shows the updates, but the photos are of the old version)

(Please, click the like button if you like it!)

This thing provides a means of mounting a caliper to your lathe without modification to the caliper. A shield is included to protect the lathe operator's hand from injury as well as protecting the caliper jaws from damage while using the equipment. This is a remix of Bot719's excellent bracket. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17970. Many thanks to the original designers! I've printed this and it works well. I'll post photos soon along with some other caliper brackets I'm working on. Caliper Model: http://www.harborfreight.com/6-inch-digital-caliper-47257.html Lathe Model: http://www.harborfreight.com/7-inch-x-10-inch-precision-mini-lathe-93212.html Likes, makes and comments are appreciated!

I printed this on a Robo3D using MatterHackers ABS. Extruder at 240 and bed at 90. Raft layers = 0, Solid Layers 4 top & bottom.

Installation of the caliper requires disassembly to allow the slide to pass through the bracket. No other modification is required, however I did remove the depth rod.

What's a Squeepop? A bigger question might be: "What isn't it?"

SQUEE: as in squeegee for spreading flat your blue tape concoction on your printer bed and making all those bubbles go away. Stop wearing out the edge of your Sears charge card and use one of the 6 (yes 6!) handy dandy edges on the SqueePop!

POP: as in pop a part that has stuck so well to your blue tape off your printer bed without scratching the aluminum, breaking the glass or worse yet: destroying your favorite screwdriver!

I estimate that SQUEEPOP will enter the national vocabulary within 6 months and be a featured word added to Webster's Dictionary by 2017...at latest.

By the way, it also works as a scraper for cleaning your printer bed. But seriously, SqueePopScraper would be a silly name.

title: 2.5" HDD OS Disk Under 5.25" ODD - HP MicroServer

description.text:
This is an additional part used in my HP MicroServer N40L Build to maximize the number of drives that could be installed inside of the case. By adding 2x 3.5" HDD's into the 5.25" ODD Bay, there needs to be a location for the OS Disk (If you're not using the USB Port on the Motherboard).

This bracket mounts to 2.5" Hard Drives / SSDs through the 4 counter-sunk holes on the bottom of the bracket. Optionally using M3 Washers as Spacers (for slight separation between PCB and Plastic), the 2.5" OS HDD is securely mounted to the bracket. The bracket is then slid through the Square on the bottom of the ODD Tray, and then fastened with Zip Ties as seen in the photos (Credit to DogBert for Installation Photos)

Mine differs from DogBert's (thing:244908) because I wanted the securing bolts underneath the drive to have a slimmer left-to-right profile. This allows for easy routing of wires, especially after splitting power multiple times to accommodate 2 additional drives in the ODD Bay. I tried to make the base sturdy with a little bit of thickness to also accommodate for the counter-sunk bolts. I tried to minimize the plastic used with removing the diamond in the middle. Using multiple perimeters maintains the structural integrity of the part.

The HP Microserver is a powerful, inexpensive, compact server tower that typically supports 4 Drives in the Bottom Bays, but with 2 PCI-e card slots available on the motherboard, the computer is capable of connecting many more HDD's.

Most people have used a Nexus Doubletwin, but looking at the price, lack of modification, shipping time / prices, I decided to design my own bracket. You can optionally use O-Rings, or insulated standoffs of some sort to minimize vibration from the disks (Home Depot / Lowes)

Mine came out to about $1.60 for both halves, and the bracket uses the HP Microserver’s included ODD Screws on the hinged door. (15% Infill Hexagonal, 3 bottom, 4 top, 3 perimeters, PLA)

I designed this a little while ago, just got around to posting it, I believe it’s a 5mm gap between thick hard drives. I used 3 TB Drives in the pictures, which are 3 platter disks. They’re pretty thick, so this bracket should fit most, if not all, hard drives. My measurements are in the pictures as well if anybody would like to check theirs.

Pictured on my MicroServer, I have 4 Drives in the bottom bays, 2 in the top bays, and a 2.5” OS drive from an older laptop underneath the ODD Bay. Totaling 6 Data disks, and 1 OS Disk. I have two cards on the HP Proliant pictured above:

  1. Syba 2-Port USB 3.0 and 2-Port SATA III PCIe 2.0 x4 SD_PEX50055 Green, Grey from Amazon ($40.01). I use this on the full size PCI-e channel on the outboard edge of the motherboard.

  2. VANTEC 4-Port SuperSpeed USB 3.0 PCIe Host Card Model UGT-PC341 from Newegg (24$). I use this one on the smaller size PCI-e channel on the inboard edge of the motherboard.
    Using these two cards I have support for 6x External USB 3.0 Disks, 6x Internal 3.5” Data Disks, 1x2.5” OS Disk, 1x ESATA Disk, and 6x USB 2.0 Disks. This gives me ~ 12 Full Speed Data Disks before I need up upgraded cases / systems.

I recommend upgrading to the latest modded BIOS so you get full performance on the on-board SATA port on the Motherboard. Also uploading the 2.5” OS HDD Under ODD Tray I designed.

Any questions please feel free to message me!

-Sibobby1

As mentioned in the Description, I used 3mm PLA from Ultimachine, I believe I used 3 Perimeters, 3 Bottom Layers, 4 Top Layers ( I don't have a fan), 15% Hexagonal Infill.

  1. Print Part using Above / Similar Settings that work for your printer.
  2. Using 4x M3 Bolts (short, if not use Hacksaw to Shorten), secure the Hard Drive to the bracket
    OPTIONAL: Use M3 Washers to create a separation between the PCB and the Plastic
  3. Angle the Drive and Bracke through the Square under the ODD Bay as seen in Description Photos
  4. Ensure the bottom Zip-Tie Channels line up with the cutouts on the metal to ensure drive goes into place securely.
  5. Route Zip Ties (Preferably Thin not to interfere with Drives). Check photos for clarity.
  6. Zip Tightly, and check the fit with attempting to move the OS Disk around.
  7. Connect SATA Power and SATA Data.
  8. Be sure to balance your rails on the HP MicroServer Power Supply. (Don't run 6 Drives off 1 of the 3 rails).
  9. Post Thanks / Post your builds, Let me know of any modifications or ideas, check out my build, leave a comment, or a donation if I saved you some money on your build :P
  10. Checkout my other parts for this same Server: (thing:937922)

Thanks guys
Have fun, enjoy the server.

comments.text: Just printed this and it came out awesome!    I'm up to 9 drives in my N40L.   Four 3.5 Internal, 4 2.5 in an 5.25 enclosure, and then the OS drive in between them all.

The bike dynamo Wind Turbine (Shimano Capreo DH-F703 6v 3.0w Dynamo QR Front Hub)

So I wanted some more power :) and took my previous design and incorporated the 6v 3.0w bike dynamo made the blades a bit bigger, add some weight to them by putting a 6 mm filleted rod true them, this gives extra weight so the blades can turn the dynamo. Smooth the blades a bit more, the housing is the same size as the previous version, just extended the tail section.
On the test run max output measured 15v.(some parts are diferent on the video than the stl file, the ones uploaded are the latest version,could not reprint having some printer issues z motor controler(: )

I'v printed all parts in PLA, the blade and cone parts at 0.2 layer hight with 0.7 shell thickness, 0.6 top/bottom thicknessprint all blade parts and the cone 3 times. Housing 0.3 ayer hight with 0.7 shell thickness 0.9 top/bottom thickness.Used 3 x 16mm aluminium tube for extending the tail section, 350mm length each.

title: BabyBEE - SurveilZone HS1151 FPV Cam Tilt 15°
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is the 15° tilt for the Surveilzone HS1151 FPV micro CAM.

The camera is a press fit into this mount, so added fastening should not be necessary. However if you want more security, then use 2 M2x6 and screw them inside the holes on the sides and secure camera with rubber band.
The mount with the camera is secured using a M3x6 from the bottom off the BabyBEE frame.

Link to the camera - http://www.surveilzone.com/0.008lux-520tvl-mini-fpv-camera-90-degree-view-angle-3.6-24v-hs1151

Please note that surveilzone is coming with a replacement lens for it, which is wider FOV. So please check this before ordering.
Print in high quality 100 micron or less. The print should be a perfect press fit for the camera.

author: BirdsEye

title: Flashforge Creator Pro Ikea Jansjo Light Mount

description.text:
I saw these lamps at Ikea on sale for $7 and couldn't resist. Seemed like the perfect thing to add extra light to my printer instead of the flashlight I was using.
I didn't find any brackets I really liked for mounting these to my printer so I made this. It uses two existing holes and screws so nothing extra is needed besides the printer and the light.
From the location I mounted it, the light will reach both the front and top of the printer depending on where you want the light.

I've included two versions:
Up: is the one pictured, it puts the light in a more useful position.
Front: if you want the light sticking out of the front,

Here is a link to the light: http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/20169658/

I printed mine in ABS 0.3mm layers with 25% infill. Seems more that sturdy enough.

I've included the OpenSCAD code used to make both versions if someone wants to modify it.

comments.text: Turns out my used Flashforge Creator Pro is the 2016 model and has the Left opening door. And these parts do not fit the panel mounting screws. They fit the earlier 2015 FFCR. FYI.

comments.text: If you tell me the dimensions you need, I will help make a version that will fit for you. H

holder_offset = 0.0
holder_y_count = 1
holder_x_size = 30
holder_angle = 0.0
taper_ratio = 1.0
holder_y_size = 30

This is a small 200m test print of some threaded rod I made along with a matching nut. It is a double helix with 1 turn per 50mm. The math works out like this: For a standard 200 step/ rev stepper motor
50mm / 200 step = .25mm per step
add in a 2:1 gearing or half step motor controller and you have .125 mm/step
add both and it's .0625 mm/step From what i can tell, there is no perceptible backlash and the nut slides very freely. I'm sure I'm going to incorporate this into my shuttle system or a printer somehow.
Enjoy... Edit:
As per request, Here's a video of it: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hkjf8x__SrE
The video shows that it's loose enough to slip down on it's own.
I would recommend printing one to test tolerances for yourself. Edit 6/18/2011
Uploaded the quad helical nut/thread. This should help with any wear issues, as well as addressing any concerns with backlash.

Print some threads,
print a nut
The center of the threaded rod is hollow, connect multiple pieces using a 5mm rod. The nut might be a little tight at first. Once you work it on the threaded rod, the interior edges become very smooth.

comments.text: Is there any CW/RH equivalent of this available?
comments.author: sekarpdkt

comments.text: Amazing, I printed the 4 start one and after just a little bit of working the nut the rod literally falls through with no effort. Has anyone tried using this as a replacement for threaded rod?
comments.author: cris11368

comments.text: Is there a way to arc an extrusion?  Basically I'd like to use this code, but arc the extruded rod somewhat, say by 5 or 10%.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I'm not quite sure what you mean by "Arc the extrusion rod". If the threaded rod had a curve along it's length, I do not believe the nut would be able to twist along it.
comments.author: Guest

comments.text: If the curve is slight in relation to the thread pitch, and the nut is not too tight, then it'll turn. They use this idea in telescopes - see the "curved rod mount" picture here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barn_door_trackerhttp://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B... and also here's a guy that made some by bending straight bolts: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HjEIJ3t4jnIhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v...

comments.author: danielpublic

comments.text: I may have to try that. Earlier this year, I attempted to do a casting using ABS in place of the "lost foam". I figured that because ABS has a high degree of styrene, it would vaporize. It didn't work out so well. Only portions of the ABS vaporized, then the aluminum set to quickly to vaporize the rest. I will have to try again with PLA.
comments.author: danielpublic

comments.text: I think this will work very well, especially if one could design something that could pack the 'core-mixture' evenly around a talcum powdered PLA piece. Have a look at this: http://reprap.org/wiki/High_Temperature_Metal_Casting#Coreshttp://reprap.org/wiki/High_Te...

comments.text:
I printed out the nut and screw, but can't quite wind the latter through the former. Is it possible to carefully gouge out the nut's channels? Would simply sanding the interior help? I'd prefer to keep the printed look on the screw itself
Ã¢Â€Â¦
comments.author: garthk

comments.text: Maybe a light sanding of the threaded rod would help. Initially, the fit was tight for mine as well, after working the nut on the thread for a few minutes, it loosened up to the point where it spun freely on it's own.
comments.author: garthk

comments.text: What are your plans to deal with wear?
comments.author: TheRuttmeister

comments.text: One other way to account for the high angle is to add more tracks. As you know a normal leadscrew has 1 helical. This is printed with 2, I could easily make it 4 to share the shear forces more evenly. 4 might be a good test and would probably be preferable provided that it doesn't add too much friction.
comments.author: TheRuttmeister

comments.text: It DOES have a very high lead angle. I may print the nut out of PLA so it doesn't wear as fast, it will slip more. I had also considered dipping the nut in a tough, thin epoxy to "fill" the gaps between the threads. Until I build a threaded-propelled shuttle, I won't know how fast it wears. So far, it seems alright.
comments.author: TheRuttmeister

comments.text: PLA and ABS gears together will make the ABS one wear out fast. So that one might not work.
comments.author: PacManFan

comments.text: At what layer height are you printing? Looks pretty fine.
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: The real trick is to match the model up with my known layer height. In the scad file, I use the extrude function with 256 steps, that's exactly the # of layers when the model is sliced at .40mm

title: Cokin P filter to 4x4 filter adapter plate

This little adapter plate allows you to snap in a Cokin P filter and use it as a 4x4 filter for your matte boxes. This is so you can either start, or expand your filter selection on the cheap.

Recommend printing in black PLA or ABS to minimize stray light reflection in your matte box. Print with support material, then snap in your filter!

author: ystrt

title: Six (or three) lobe 5.8 GHz circular polarized antenna template kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Kit for "easily" building 6 lobe LHCP/RHCP 5.8GHz antennas for FPV.

  • Can be used both for VRx and VTx.
    The template allows you to reproduce the antennas to create matching pairs for both VTx and VRx as well as creating spares that match your existing antennas.

How to use the template and build an antenna: https://youtu.be/8PKhqbBy2ls

Use the SPW58 template for best results.

Note: If you are just looking to save a few bucks on an antenna, this is probably not for you.

Print all items at 0.1 layer height, solid infill, ABS. Do not use PLA - it will melt when soldering. You can get away with printing the pingpong ball cutting tool with 15% infill.

To create the traditional cloverleaf antenna, simply use 3 instead of 6 lobes.

To build an antenna you need:

Tools:

  • Needle nose pliers
  • Soldering station
  • Solder
  • Hot glue gun
  • Heat gun
  • Exacto knife
  • Cue tip
  • Isopropyl alcohol

Materials:

  • 400mm 0.5mm copper wire (or 0.8mm MIG welding wire)
  • 46.5 mm semi-rigid flexible RG402 0.141" RF coaxial cable
  • 40mm ping-pong ball
  • SMA (or RP-SMA) Male Plug Solder For Semi-Rigid RG402 0.141" Cable RF Connector
  • 25mm Ø6mm heat shrink
  • CA glue

How to:
1) Use the bending template to cut the wire (6 pieces) to length and bend the wire at 90 degree angles using a set of pliers.
2) Then bend the wire to fit the template.
3) Now twist the lobe 45 degrees left or right to create a LHCP or RHCP antenna.
4) Assemble the Six lobe alignment wheel with with the six lobe alignment wheel center.
5) Place the 6 lobes in the alignment wheel and secure them with a dap of hot glue.
7) cut 3mm of the insulation of the RG402 wire at each end, exposing the inner core.
8) Remove the six lobe alignment wheel center and place one end of the RG402inside the 6 pegs of the lobes.
9) Cut the heat shrink into 3 pieces: 10mm/10mm/5mm
10) place the 5mm piece of heat shrink over the 6 pegs of the lobes and carefully heat the heat shrink with the heat gun WITHOUT melting the hot glue (or ABS) - The pegs and RG402 are now somewhat secured.
11) Solder the pegs to the RG402 once again careful not to melt the hot glue or ABS.
12) Remove the 5mm piece of heat shrink with an exacto knife
13) place on 10mm piece of heat shrink around the 6 pegs and the RG402 and gently heat with the heat gun to shrink it into place
14) align the lobes with the 3mm stump of core and carefully solder them in place.
15) Using the cue tip, dap some isopropyl alcohol onto the hot glue and remove the hot glue once the isopropyl alcohol has done its magic.
16) Remove the antenna from the alignment wheel.
17) Place a 10mm piece of heat shrink on the RG402 as close to the loops as possible - do not shrink it!
18) Place the Six lobe dome base on the antenna.
19) Solder the SMA peg onto the RG402 core
20) solder the SMA connector onto the RG402 cable
21) Push the 10mm piece of heat shrink over the SMA connector base and heat to shrink into place.
22) Glue the six lobe dome base to the base of the antenna (heat shrink) to secure it to the antenna.
23) Place a ping-pong ball between the two halves of the ping-pong ball cutting tool (The "seem" of the ball should go opposite the cutting direction for easiest cut).
24) use the exacto knife to gradually cut though the ball
25) Place one half of the ball onto the six lobe dome base and secure it with CA.

description.text:

The Customizer can produce variants with uniform sized cells.   
For boxes with mixed size cells, and combinations of fixed and removable dividers, see examples in the openscad script.  
Design withdrawn due to lawsuit by Stratasys.

author: bobc

title: Nesting 11 lobed bowl
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I print these in vase mode with a 0.75mm nozzle and a 2mm nozzle setting in mattercontrol. 0.6mm layer height, 3 base layers and 10mm/sec head speed. Prints a really solid feeling bowl that nests nicely. vaguely reminiscent of cane furniture with that chunky layer size. Be sure to keep the ratio of layer thickness to nozzle print diameter at 0.3:1 or lower.

Remember, no fill, no top layers, slow fat print, fan full on, vase mode.
Scale up to fit your printer and make sure you have plenty of filament on your reel.

description.text: Fans of Patrick McGoohanâ€™s classic BBC spy series The Prisoner will recognize this gimmick from Episode 15, â€œThe Girl Who Was Death.â€ As the beer or other libation is drained, the lines of text becomes visible at the bottom of the glass. Personally, I think I would probably stop drinking after "have," but hey... This is a stencil, in an authentic "Village" font, for applying etching cream to the bottom of a pint glass. They're intended to be made on adhesive vinyl using a vinyl cutter. If you don't have one, they are available for $2.00 apiece (and up, depending on the size you want) from etchworld: http://www.etchworld.com/ecom-prodshow/c-misc-0002.html
The process is pretty simple, but instructions for applying the stencil and etching the design are here: http://makeprojects.com/Project/You-Have-Just-Been-Poisoned/957/1

author: lezun73

title: Parametric sprinkle nozzle for watering can

description.text:
In case you lost or broke the sprinkle nozzle for your watering can, or want a different spray pattern, look no further.

The holes are "drilled" in a slant fashion, helping to get a nice spray pattern.

The default neck diameter is 25mm, slightly coned, but you can change this.

The form of the main cone is controlled by cone_dia (cone diameter assuming no bevel) and cone_len (cone length, or height if you wish), but also by cone_bevel, which controls the size of the beveled part along the circumference. Do not make the cone_len too small compared to cone_dia, or you will have problems building the resulting flat angle properly.

Parameter wall is the general wall thickness. A thinner wall means shorter print time, but do not make it too flimsy.

The spray pattern is controlled by the parameters nozzle_dia (size of each opening) and nozzle_dist (distance between openings). Reduce nozzle_dia and nozzle_dist to get a softer spray.
Should be a straight build, with no support needed. Do not use a brim support, since it will clog the holes.

A friend needed a simple way to keep a cable in place, so we designed this clip to snap into two RCA connectors.

Though the model is upright, I recommend printing it on the side like shown in the picture.

We printed 8 of theese, and they worked directly out of the printer, no post-print cleanup required.

When we printed it standing up, like in the model, the quality was MUCH lower, and strength was very poor. Also it would have required ALOT of cleaning up with a knife or sanding it, not worth it when printing it on the side solves all problems.

description.text: I have the Geeetech i3 pro C. The z axis was wobbling so I created the small ones fist and saw it was working then I created the bigger ones. Its was a quick make so use prestick to fit the block nicely if to small or sand it if to big. Enjoy!

comments.text: Have you ever tried to flip your lead screw and see whether the clamped end is bent or not? Mine was the case and solved it. But I used my top axis bracket to further reduce the wobble threat
comments.author: sarf2k4

comments.text: I only removed the threaded rod and saw it was bent, did not checked the lead screw. But I did notice my one lead screw was a bit loose, which was strange towards my other lead screw while my x-axis was straight. So maybe mine is bent, but mine works great now. Thanks for the comment tho, will most likely help people with z-axis problems.
comments.author: sarf2k4

comments.text: In my context, z-axis threaded rod is the lead screw, some people also calls them that. x-axis is not what you should be worrying because these smooth rods not easy to bend compared to lead screws
comments.author: Danie_Grobbelaar

comments.text: O crap yeah, my mistake. But no I did not checked that. I only taken it out and rolled it on a flat surface and tried to take a the bent out which was hard to do. In your case were you only turned the screw around, did your couplings seemed to wobble?
comments.author: sarf2k4

comments.text: I bought mine from an agent, turned out to be coupler supplied didn't grip the lead screw. I had to print an anti wobble coupler instead. After fitting them in, I noticed the head goes back and forth during high speed homing on z axis. The agent asked me to use stock coupler, make video for replacement, I tried to replace with the lead screw I bought from hardware but I can't make it fit. Long story short (hopefully) when I tried to take out the supplied lead screw from the bottom end, it is somewhat stuck at the end of the rod and had to use pliers to force it.
comments.author: Danie_Grobbelaar

comments.text: Wow seems you went through a lot. Setting up a 3D printer is harder than we thought, right? or some are just luckier than other. But I guess we learn a lot by it or something. Lol. After weeks of struggling feels good to finally be able to start printing some good quality stuff. I thought I was never going to print cool stuff I see other printers print.
comments.author: sarf2k4

comments.text: Yes I do, even after receiving it and assembled it, the board supplied were bricked as well. Not to mention that there were no statement saying the axis must have fluid motion, then the stepstick were fried cause the board tried to move the axis due to bricked. Delayed another 1 month for that, I did ordered a separate ramps set but terminal got burnt because I used solid core wire (from psu to ramps input terminal). Even after that, I realized the coupler won't grip the lead screw even I tightened it, that's why I stuffed something in it, then I think that's the main reason it got bent in the first place.
comments.author: Danie_Grobbelaar

comments.text: I had the same Problem, after printing the Anti-Wobbling upgrade (the Link from ronindev) i have no Problems with wobbles so you can see the differenc my Yoda Buddha was printed bevorder and the darhvader Buddha with the Anti-Wobbling upgrade

Here's a video explaining the spool holder...
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fcPFLtofpFk&feature=youtu.be

This is my solution to fix common problems related to Taulman brand Spools... This design is based roughly on a popular Spool holder design I made a few years ago... http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:290064 ...

Taulman makes great filament, but their spools are packed to the brim, very tight, with no place the keep the end of the filament controlled... This causes a lot of the spool to completely unwind everywhere... You can either cut it off and waste the filament, or try to wrap it back up and risk getting a snag or your spool locking up later while printing.... My spool holder has a place to keep the end of the filament held... And lockers which lock the spool in place - restricting it from spinning when you don't want it to spin... The dimensions of the spool holder are near perfect, so everything will fit and screw in well - even on low resolution...

Thanks for viewing my spool holder - be sure to like it... I hope you find it useful!!!

FilamentChallenge

Print 1 Base Arm, 1 Spinner Arm, and 3 Rods...

Settings can be either .1mm,.2mm, or .3mm or whatever you want for layer height...

Infill doesn't matter... At least 10%...

If you want to make it stronger I suggestion printing with 3 shells or perimeters for strength in the screws... Especially on the base arm...

UPDATED: A raised boss was added to make it easy to align the two parts of the joint and an access hole was added for shafts, cables, wire harnesses, candy, etc. How should we attach one object to another in the world of 3D printing? Two complex parts that have the details to hook together would be better than a bunch of parts, nuts and bolts. These two simple parts are connected with a double row T-lock style bayonet joint as a way to explore that idea. Perfect to join parts for an object that is larger than your build volume ... or for that removable droid arm. Here's a video of how it works: http://youtu.be/-jOLMR73O1E Enjoy! Scott Vader

This was created in Solidworks 2013. The files are attached. I've also uploaded photos of the 5 steps to create the male T-lock.  
Step 1 - create one or more rows of T lock profiles in a 2D sketch, then make a helical path, then sweep the 2D sketch along the helical path.   
Step 2 - cut off the top of the helical sweep to make a wedge shape.  
Step 3 - copy the T locks around a central axis in this case 5 times. Three or more should work.  
Step 4 - revolve a rectangle to create a base for the T locks  
Step 5 - add a handle so we can test this thing  
The female starts with the same file but then flips the operations around to make them negative. If this was a machined part a clearance of 0.1 mm or 0.004" would be fine. With my Ultimaker I needed to reduce the narrow male features by 0.5 mm and increase narrow female features by 0.7 mm to respect the design. These files include those adjustments. Hopefully that works well for your 3D printer too.

description.text:
This is a simple lens cap for your Xiaomi Yi camera.
Fit's perfectly!
I continue to work on new mirrored x axis

Remember to leave me a tip if you think that my work is great! As a student I really appreciate it!

Smart and cool way to tie your shoes fast.

Why are Klöts better than normal shoelaces?

  • It is faster way to tie your shoes.
  • They look personal and cool.
  • They will always stay at the same tension. (Super useful for sports)
  • There is no unnecessary ends of shoelaces hanging.
  • Fully customizable

!!! Remember to thread Klöts flat side pointing up. Curvy side will press against your shoe to make sure that shoelaces will pull Klöts away from each other not down. When the pull is away from each other it prevents Klöts open in action!!!

There are 3 different models available:

Klöts 3 - For small shoes and kids shoes
Klöts 4 - For average sized shoes
Klöts 5 - For big shoes and boots

27.7.2015
Added strips to make Klöts look even cooler and more personal.

How to use?

  1. Print Klöts (and strips)
    (1.2 Super glue strips in place)
  2. Undo your shoelaces
  3. Thread shoelaces through Klöts
  4. Make sure that the tension is right
  5. In the end make really tight knots
  6. Put the rest of your shoelaces into the shoes.

comments.text:
Hello! Nice version!
For me and my printer the tolerance has been just right at least. It might vary between different printers. In my design I didn't want to close off opposite ends of each because I wanted them to be as easy as possible to open and close with both hands (and both ways). My design should really not come apart if they are installed correctly. I have been using these for 4 years now and they have opened only twice while doing sports. I think that tolerance doesn't even matter that much. Closing mechanism is working so that the tension is pulling Klöts apart from each other. Ramp like shape makes sure that tension really pulls Klöts apart and not bends and flexes.

title: Customizable Firefighter Door Chock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is my "Hello World" Customizer thing. We use wedges like these to block open doors like a doorstop or at the hinge. Two wedges can be pushed together inside the frame of a sprinkler head to shut off the (copious) flow of water. Not sure if ABS is up to the stresses of closing a sprinkler head - I guess I will have to test. Print it in a bright color so that you don't lose it on the fireground. Add your own initials or employee number. I printed dozens of hand-customized wedges for my buddies before I figured out how to parametrically create the same thing using OpenSCAD. This is currently designed only for the Black Rose font. I am not delighted with the font, but it is a nice change from blocky Tinkercad letters. I will be figuring out how to munge other fonts onto the shape appropriately. If you have suggestions about how to brute-force text onto shapes, I am all ears. Work in progress. Stay tuned, based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43931

ATTENTION
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial license. This license applies only to the files and documents available for download from the Thing Files section of this Thing.
All other related content (photographs, videos, and verbiage such as contained in "Description" or "Instructions" ) are excluded from this license. with all rights reserved, unless specifically available for download This notice constitutes a clarification, not a change, to licensing for this design.

To date, the only parameters you can change are the size of the hole and the lettering. You can fit more letters in lower case. Your wedge will have the same letters and/or numbers top and bottom. Interestingly, in the OpenSCAD script, I could not get numbers to render properly with Write.scad until I converted them to a string with str(). I haven't commented that in the code yet, so I am putting it here for now. If you have an interest in affecting other parameters, let me know!
Thanks
schlem

comments.author: schlem

comments.text: We wear all kinds of synthetic materials on the fire ground - some heat resistant, some not so much. Our face masks are made from Lexan, which begins to soften at about 300ºF. The flash point of ABS is 404ºC (759ºF).  If you're in an environment that is too hot for an ABS wedge on your helmet, it's too hot for you.  About 40 guys in my department carry these wedges and nobody has melted one yet.
comments.author: schlem

comments.text: What Infill have you been using, a bunch of my guys want these with their monitor #'s on them.
comments.author: schlem

comments.text: I think I printed most of them at 50% infill. I have yet to perform a mechanical failure test. I'm pretty sure a steel door could crush one in the jamb. Haven't tried in a sprinkler heard yet, but it should be narrow enough, maybe with a dime on the valve?
comments.author: Dogodile

comments.text: I meant to mention that the numbers add vital strength in the middle of the chock, in that there is a solid web of plastic generated by the slicer software that supports the inside of the negative spaces. I used 3 vertical layers and two perimeters.
comments.author: schlem

comments.text: Never though that the numbers add those layers in slicer, therefore increasing strength. I plasti-dipped one chock i have unsure if it'll stop a sprinkler (it'll slow it anyhow and usually someone has a rubber chock), or how long it will stick. Plastidip almost seems to imbed into the abs layers. Time will tell how it'll hold up.
comments.author: schlem

comments.text: Cool! Keep me posted! I'd love to hear how it works.
comments.author: Dogodile

comments.text: Is it clever to take a platic door chock into a fire?

description.text:
The Module called danger used in this file is thoroughly swiped from Dippo's Danger sign http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9365
All the polygons were built using Pieterbos' Polygon generator http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9290 I think the original logo was from a SomethingAwful.com Photoshop Phriday in the late 90's. A cohort printed it off and I made a stencil out of it to place on several objects... It's a bit jagged and I'm recalling the shape from memory, so I may make a fixed version at some stage!

• Scale to fit your printer
  • Print
  • Place in your local "Danger Zone" on a high contrast background as warning against self-immolation
  • Save countless lives
  • Bask in your good deed

title: External Spool Holder for Flashforge Dreamer

description.text:
A spool holder that attaches anywhere at the bottom of the printer. No screws required! I attach it to the back so the spool feeds the nozzle nicely. Doesn't only fit the standard 0.6kg Flashforge spool, but also the typical 1kg spool.

Update: I just received a wider 1kg that won't fit this spool holder. So I've created a 2nd large spacer and rod to fit the larger spool and added to the download list.

comments.text: Just a friendly warning; this works great, but PLEASE NOTE it's for hanging off the edge off a table. This WILL NOT WORK if you want the 1kg spool the same surface as your Dreamer. The large spool cannot fit on it if it's on a flat surface. I made this mistake... so now have to dance around a spool hanging off my desk... :'(
comments.author: Tinufel

comments.text: Thanks for your feedback Tinufel. I know what you mean but it really depends on the size of your spool. I have a few 1 kg spools that fit without the need of hanging of the side of the table. These spools are wider and have a smaller radius which is the template I designed the holder for. You probably could extend the design of the holder by another circle to make your spool fit.
comments.author: Tinufel

comments.text: I'm slowly working on an extension for your design :-) All my 1kg spools seem too "long" if you get me. There's a limit to how big I can print it because of  the build platform size so extension is the answer ^_^ Or a smaller diameter inner tube insert.... :-D I'll hopefully report back one day with a solution :-D I honestly love the design otherwise.

description.text:
This box allows you to fix the OP revonano board on a standard 30.5mm footprint.
It allows the routing of cables under the case.

Based on Fredrik Arvidsson original OpenPilot design (m-thread on forums) published here: http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showpost.php?p=32005213&postcount=195

Print in ABS at 0.14mm, or any material which allows post processing.
The top cover holes need to be reamed to 3mm.
The holes in the bottom box must be threaded for M3 screws.

It's printed with the Zortrax M200 with Z-ABS filament.
Because of the precise tolerances required to lock the board, I have no idea how it could be with other brand printers.
Disintegrator 1934 Buck Rogers gun (Foo Fighters album gun)
This model will need to be built using support.

Do your own "cartel luminoso" (signboards, placard?? I don't know how to say that in english, sorry) with LEDs strips!!!
I made a full alphabet for you!! So you can print the words you want, put inside the LED strip and It will be already to use!!

I made "EL NARDO" for my xaranga, ( a kind of music band here in spain), It's 0,75 metres long, with RGB LEDs strips.
We went to play in a band contest, and I proposed to make something cool with my 3D printer, something new, something anybody has, but the "boss" said no, but I thought it will be a good idea, so I made it and I give it to my xaranga as a surprise!!
All of them were in shock when they saw it few minutes before our turn to play !! And now we use it in every gig!!!!!!!

People use to take photos with it when we are playing, and anyone believe my when I say I made it with a 3D printer!!!!!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A4DXmNQbqMU

aaaah!! I'm the tuba, you can see me playing in front of my creation!!! :D:D
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CDSohpuKoVA

Now I made another as a present for a friend of mine, he plays the clarinet in the video, when he saw the nardo's placard he ask me If I can do it bigger for his company and of course I can!!! 2m LONG!!!!!
This year, during the town's festivities, he is going to be the captain of his company: LLAURADORS, ( villajoiosa, Spain), and this is his present for them!!

The premiere is tomorrow (24/07/2015), I will take photos and videos!! I'm very nervious, because I don't know what the reaction of the people will be!!

  • The font of LLAURADORS is different because it is like the logo of the company, but it's the same design for the bottom and top side than the alphabet I uploaded

https://youtu.be/QB3zKkhmouE

it was a success!!!!! The people of the LLAURADORS company love it!!
this is the moment when they saw it!
*I'm the guy with the blue t-shirt, I was playing with my xaranga, El Nardo, in other company, i went to see the result of my job

http://youtu.be/n9hWr8s7DjA

• Download the zip files, STL or SLDPRT,

  • Choose the letters you need (without misspellings)

  • Print the top and the bottom of every letter

    • you can print everything with transparent filament, like EL NARDO or print the bottom in the colour you want and the top in transparent or natural filament like LLAURADORS

  • Put the led strip in the bottom side, the holes is for the wires, to connect the letters

  • close the letter with the top side, use super glue

    • I only made the holes for the wires, I don't made any hole to fix it, because it depends where and how you want to use it,
      because of that, I upload the sldprt files ( Solidworks), so you can edit it!!

    • tip: for " LLAURADORS" I made the holes to fix it in a L profile, using M8 screw, I put the nut into the bottom side using the soldering iron.
      And the distance between holes is 25mm, so i put every hole in the letter at 25, 50 ,75...

the size of the screw, and the way to fix it depend on you, even you can use superglue to fix it

Also you need:

  • LED stripe
  • wires
  • Soldering iron
  • super glue

PLA 0,2mm layer / ~2mm walls and 20% infill.

This is one of the three series of rubber band powered that I have made. There are two photo attachment of the previous version of the model.

Until this model is printed, the obstacles that I face is that I get all four wheels are angled hole, or holes not perpendicular and make wheel shake when turning. And the upper part of the body is too high causes a nut and bolt holes slightly shifted due to swaying during printing.

This material you need:

  1. M3 nut and bolt length 10mm
  2. 1 piece of rubber band
  3. Paperclips cut 30mm: 2 pieces
  4. Loosespokes bike (diameter: 1.94mm) cut 80mm: 2 pieces
  5. Rapid cure adhesive (Cyanoacrylate Adhesive)
  6. lubricant spray, which I used to use in my bicycle chain

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2BVbFBmpapg

1. Print all one piece while for car5 -_ wheel.STL 4 pieces, then car5 -_ wing.STL 2 pieces, infill 100%, the layer just 0.2mm height for car5 -_ wheel.STL with layer height 0.1mm. Use brim 2 mm.

  2. Cut all brim with scissors, sandpaper remaining brim with sandpaper no. 80 and no. 320.

  3. Put the two wings on either a rectangular hole in the body with cyanoacrylate glue.

  4. If the hole in propeller closed filament, drill holes using a 0.8 mm diameter.

  5. Shape curved with sandpaper number 80 flat propeller tip given brim.

  6. Balance the propeller by inserting a large needle into the lock, turn it several times and mark the lightest part is the propeller that is above. Sandpaper section below, and then play a few times, check whether the sides of propeller was at the same level or not, if not repeat sanding parts heavier until balanced.

  7. Sandpaper touching side is at the wheel and propeller, the first to use sandpaper sandpaper number 80 and number 320 last danyang number 1000.

  8. Cut the paper clip along the 30 mm, 5 mm bend forming hurupf u with a width of approximately 1.5 mm, and insert it into the hole in propeller. Do the same thing as the other propeller.

  9. Insert the two propeller and hook paperclip into the hole in hoder, created the arch at the other end by using pliers and a screw M4 to make the circle as a hook a rubber band. Do the same for the other propeller.

  10. Put a rubber band around both the hook and attach the holder already installed propeller and rubber bands to the body with the nuts and bolts M3 size with a length of 10 mm.

  11. Cut with a chainsaw bicycle spokes with a 80mm length is 2 pieces.

  12. Give a cyanoacrylate glue one end of the bicycle spokes that have been cut and enter the tires let the glue dry, insert it into the hole in the front of the body and then glue the other end and put the other tires. Do this also for the rear wheels.

  13. Put all the parts that need lubrication.

comments.text: I don't recommend abs as most abs filaments are not food safe as they contain various chemicals in the material. If the machine is to come into contact with food I would suggest using a fda approved food safe filament such as t-glasse or a pla filament. With the pla filament you can handwash the machine with soap and water.

comments.text: I don't upload objects with builtin supports as people have their own preferences as to how to generate print supports and every software has it's own way of handling builtin supports. This was intended more as a proof of concept then something I was going to print out, but its available to all who wish to try. Note: do not be alarmed by the large number of parts. Many of then are duplicates made from converting the solid works assembly into an stl file.
